awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: IceCube Data Analysis in the U.S.
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for U.S. scientists to perform the scientific analysis of data taken with the IceCube Neutrino Observatory (ICNO) located at the U.S. Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station. The ICNO transformed one cubic kilometer of natural ice (at the depth from 1.4 to 2.4 km) into a giant Cherenkov emission detector, thus creating the world's largest neutrino detector above energies of approximately 10 GeV. Since its completion in 2010, the ICNO has detected neutrinos with energies spanning more than six orders of magnitude, from 10 GeV to beyond 5 PeV for the first time. (GeV = one billion electron volts; TeV = one trillion electron volts; and PeV = one quadrillion electron volts.) In 2017, the ICNO detected a neutrino with an energy of 290 TeV and its origin was pinpointed (again for the first time) to a blazar at a distance of about 3.5 million light years. This detection triggered an extensive campaign involving some twenty space- and ground-based telescopes that launched a new era in multi-messenger detection. 

The mystique of the South Pole environment and the compelling science of IceCube are an alluring mix. Besides its extensive coverage in newspapers and publications popularizing science, IceCube has a significant presence on social media and the World Wide Web. In the next three years, focused projects include the continued development of an online video game, an activity for Zooniverse, and content for their successful high school MasterClasses. These activities will also contribute to the training of the next generation of scientists by integrating graduate and undergraduate education with the IceCube technology development, astrophysical observations, and scientific analyses of the ICNO data.

The U.S. groups have established a solid and successful record of analyzing data from IceCube. This award will enable a unified analysis program which will maximize the impact of increasingly interconnected efforts. The synthesis of information from multiple astrophysical messengers is now providing a powerful new tool for probing the Universe. The highest energy messengers so far detected from the Universe are cosmic rays: high energy nuclei that are likely mostly protons. We do not yet know where or how they are accelerated to these extreme energies, but with the observation of a distant blazar in coincidence with the direction and time of a very high energy muon neutrino, neutrinos have now provided the first breakthrough in the resolution of this puzzle. The results reveal neutrinos as a key component of future multimessenger studies of the highest energy radiation reaching us from space. Thus, this award addresses and advances the science objectives and goals of the NSF's "Windows on the Universe: The Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics" program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award covered the 2019–2023 scientific analysis of data taken with the IceCube Neutrino Observatory. This period included IceCube’s identification of neutrino sources beyond the sun, including our own Milky Way. Neutrinos are nearly massless particles that travel very close to the speed of light. They are therefore essentially identical to photons, the particles of light, with one important exception: because of their feeble interaction with matter, they reach us from environments that photons cannot escape; in other words, they reach us from the beginning of time and the edge of the universe. Unfortunately, their weak interactions with matter also make neutrinos very difficult to detect. Immense particle detectors are required to collect them in sufficient numbers for making astronomy using neutrinos as astronomical messengers a reality; enter IceCube.

 

The IceCube project transformed a cubic kilometer of highly transparent natural Antarctic ice one mile below the geographic South Pole into the largest particle detector ever built. Completed in December 2010, IceCube went on to discover energetic neutrinos originating beyond our Galaxy, opening a new window for astronomy. Its initial discovery was from a collection of 28 detected neutrino events, two of which had the highest energies ever observed, above 1 PeV, or petaelectronvolts (1015 electronvolts), close to one million times the energy of neutrinos presently produced by earthbound particle accelerators. The observation was recognized as the 2013 Physics World Breakthrough of the Year.

 

Subsequent observations of high-energy neutrinos of cosmic origin by IceCube revealed that neutrinos are remarkably abundant in the extreme universe. Originating mostly outside our own Galaxy, their energy in the universe exceeds the energy in gamma rays. Unlike in any other wavelength of light, neutrino sources outside our own Galaxy outshine the neutrino flux from nearby sources inside our Galaxy. The Milky Way appears as only a faint glow at about ten percent of the total flux from other galaxies, revealing that sources of neutrinos in other galaxies are not present in our own, which is essentially a neutrino desert. The Galactic neutrino flux observed is produced in the interactions of cosmic rays with interstellar material. Where these cosmic rays actually originate, on the other hand, remains an unresolved puzzle.

 

After accumulating a decade of data, IceCube revisited the instrument’s precise geometry and calibration, achieving a significantly improved understanding of the data. The pointing and energy resolution of observed neutrinos has also been enhanced using modern machine learning techniques. This deliberate campaign resulted in larger data samples of improved quality. It also accelerated the discoveries made by IceCube. A subsequent search for neutrino sources with significantly improved sensitivity revealed the first high-energy sources in the neutrino sky: the active galaxies NGC 1068, PKS 1424+240, and TXS 0506+056. Unlike the case for our own galaxy, where the black hole is dormant, in active galaxies the central black holes are cannibalizing the radiation and gas in their own galactic environments. TXS 0506+056 had previously been identified as a neutrino source in a multimessenger campaign triggered by a neutrino of 290 TeV energy, IC170922, and by the independent observation of a neutrino burst from the source discovered in archival IceCube data in 2014.

 

The neutrino observations of NGC 1068, a nearby active galaxy, point to the acceleration of protons in the particle inflows onto the supermassive black hole at its center. Their interactions with the very dense concentrations of X-rays and gas result in the production of neutrinos in the very close vicinity of the black hole. This inspired follow-up searches for active galaxies that are strong X-ray emitters. They revealed evidence for more neutrino sources: NGC 4151, which along with NGC 1068 topped the list of active galaxies discovered by Seyfert in 1943, and Circinus, the first source pinpointed by IceCube in the Southern Hemisphere.

 

IceCube is not just a neutrino telescope, it is a multipurpose instrument for doing science, including topics in glaciology, geology, and much more. With energies exceeding those produced with earthbound accelerator beams by a factor of one million, cosmic neutrinos present a remarkable opportunity for studying the neutrinos themselves. Using the detector’s DeepCore subarray, IceCube studies the flavor oscillation patterns of atmospheric neutrinos, with results whose precision will soon exceed that obtained from dedicated accelerator experiments in the US and Japan.

 

With the mystique of the South Pole and its compelling science, the IceCube project provides a unique opportunity to engage the public and to enhance scientific and technological understanding on many levels. We have continued to use this opportunity to conduct an extensive and impactful outreach program over the period covered by the grant.
